trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing app (WP8) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing app (WP8) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to get started using data from your Azure Mobile Services Windows Phone 8 app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to get started using data from your Azure Mobile Services Windows Phone 8 app.

trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing app
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services to leverage data in a Windows Phone 8 app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services to leverage data in a Windows Phone 8 app.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will download an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then login to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will download an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then login to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.

trans-unit.source: You can also see Nick Harris demonstrate this in the following video:
trans-unit.target: You can also see Nick Harris demonstrate this in the following video:

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2012 Express for Windows Phone 8 and the [Windows Phone 8 SDK] running on Windows 8.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2012 Express for Windows Phone 8 and the [Windows Phone 8 SDK] running on Windows 8.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial to create a Windows Phone 8.1 app, you must use Visual Studio 2013 Update 2, or a later version.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial to create a Windows Phone 8.1 app, you must use Visual Studio 2013 Update 2, or a later version.

trans-unit.source: An Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <link><linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <link><linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Download the GetStartedWithData project
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Download the GetStartedWithData project

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is built on the <link><linkText>GetStartedWithData app[developer code samples site]</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a Windows Phone Silverlight 8 app project.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is built on the <link><linkText>GetStartedWithData app[developer code samples site]</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a Windows Phone Silverlight 8 app project.

trans-unit.source: Download the GetStartedWithData sample app project from the [Developer Code Samples site].
trans-unit.target: Download the GetStartedWithData sample app project from the [Developer Code Samples site].

trans-unit.source: To create a Windows Phone Silverlght 8.1 app, just change the target OS in the downloaded Windows Phone Silverlight 8 app project to Windows Phone 8.1.
trans-unit.target: To create a Windows Phone Silverlght 8.1 app, just change the target OS in the downloaded Windows Phone Silverlight 8 app project to Windows Phone 8.1.

trans-unit.source: To create a Windows Phone Store app, download the <link><linkText>Windows Phone Store app version</linkText><title></title></link> of the GetStartedWithData sample app project.
trans-unit.target: To create a Windows Phone Store app, download the <link><linkText>Windows Phone Store app version</linkText><title></title></link> of the GetStartedWithData sample app project.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the downloaded project and examine the MainPage.xaml.cs file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the downloaded project and examine the MainPage.xaml.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Notice that added TodoItem objects are stored in an in-memory ObservableCollection.
trans-unit.target: Notice that added TodoItem objects are stored in an in-memory ObservableCollection.

trans-unit.source: Press the F5 key to rebuild the project and start the app.
trans-unit.target: Press the F5 key to rebuild the project and start the app.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type some text in the text box, then click the Save button.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type some text in the text box, then click the Save button.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the saved text is displayed in the list below.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the saved text is displayed in the list below.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Create a new mobile service in the Management Portal
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Create a new mobile service in the Management Portal

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Add a new table to the mobile service
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Add a new table to the mobile service

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Update the app to use the mobile service for data access
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Update the app to use the mobile service for data access

trans-unit.source: Now that your mobile service is ready, you can update the app to store items in Mobile Services instead of the local collection.
trans-unit.target: Now that your mobile service is ready, you can update the app to store items in Mobile Services instead of the local collection.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, right-click the project name, and then select Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, right-click the project name, and then select Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, select the Online category, search for WindowsAzure.MobileServices, click Install on the Azure Mobile Services package, then accept the license agreement.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, select the Online category, search for WindowsAzure.MobileServices, click Install on the Azure Mobile Services package, then accept the license agreement.

trans-unit.source: This adds the Mobile Services client library to the project.
trans-unit.target: This adds the Mobile Services client library to the project.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, click Mobile Services, and then click the mobile service you just created.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, click Mobile Services, and then click the mobile service you just created.

trans-unit.source: Click the Dashboard tab and make a note of the Site URL, then click Manage keys and make a note of the Application key.
trans-unit.target: Click the Dashboard tab and make a note of the Site URL, then click Manage keys and make a note of the Application key.

trans-unit.source: You will need these values when accessing the mobile service from your app code.
trans-unit.target: You will need these values when accessing the mobile service from your app code.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the file App.xaml.cs and add or uncomment the following using statement:
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the file App.xaml.cs and add or uncomment the following using statement:

trans-unit.source: In this same file, uncomment the following code that defines the MobileService variable, and supply the URL and application key from the mobile service in the MobileServiceClient constructor, in that order.
trans-unit.target: In this same file, uncomment the following code that defines the MobileService variable, and supply the URL and application key from the mobile service in the MobileServiceClient constructor, in that order.

trans-unit.source: This creates a new instance of MobileServiceClient that is used to access your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This creates a new instance of MobileServiceClient that is used to access your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In the file MainPage.xaml.cs, add or uncomment the following using statements:
trans-unit.target: In the file MainPage.xaml.cs, add or uncomment the following using statements:

trans-unit.source: In this same file, replace the TodoItem class definition with the following code:
trans-unit.target: In this same file, replace the TodoItem class definition with the following code:

trans-unit.source: Comment the line that defines the existing items collection, then uncomment the following lines:
trans-unit.target: Comment the line that defines the existing items collection, then uncomment the following lines:

trans-unit.source: This code creates a mobile services-aware binding collection (items) and a proxy class for the SQL Database table TodoItem (todoTable).
trans-unit.target: This code creates a mobile services-aware binding collection (items) and a proxy class for the SQL Database table TodoItem (todoTable).

trans-unit.source: In the InsertTodoItem method, remove the line of code that sets the TodoItem.Id property, add the async modifier to the method, and uncomment the following line of code:
trans-unit.target: In the InsertTodoItem method, remove the line of code that sets the TodoItem.Id property, add the async modifier to the method, and uncomment the following line of code:

trans-unit.source: This code inserts a new item into the table.
trans-unit.target: This code inserts a new item into the table.

trans-unit.source: In the RefreshTodoItems method, add the async modifier to the method, then uncomment the following line of code:
trans-unit.target: In the RefreshTodoItems method, add the async modifier to the method, then uncomment the following line of code:

trans-unit.source: This sets the binding to the collection of items in the todoTable, which contains all TodoItem objects returned from the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This sets the binding to the collection of items in the todoTable, which contains all TodoItem objects returned from the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In the UpdateCheckedTodoItem method, add the async modifier to the method, and uncomment the following line of code:
trans-unit.target: In the UpdateCheckedTodoItem method, add the async modifier to the method, and uncomment the following line of code:

trans-unit.source: This sends an item update to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This sends an item update to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Now that the app has been updated to use Mobile Services for backend storage, it's time to test the app against Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Now that the app has been updated to use Mobile Services for backend storage, it's time to test the app against Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Test the app against your new mobile service
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Test the app against your new mobile service

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to run the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to run the app.

trans-unit.source: As before, type text in the textbox, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: As before, type text in the textbox, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: This sends a new item as an insert to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This sends a new item as an insert to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In the [Management Portal], click Mobile Services, and then click your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In the [Management Portal], click Mobile Services, and then click your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Click the Data tab, then click Browse.
trans-unit.target: Click the Data tab, then click Browse.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the TodoItem table now contains data, with id values generated by Mobile Services, and that columns have been automatically added to the table to match the TodoItem class in the app.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the TodoItem table now contains data, with id values generated by Mobile Services, and that columns have been automatically added to the table to match the TodoItem class in the app.

trans-unit.source: This concludes the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This concludes the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Phone 8 app to work with data in Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Phone 8 app to work with data in Mobile Services.
